Description: Shoulder sherd of Corinthian black-figured pottery closed vessel, probably an aryballos; exterior: at top, wide painted black band with pairs of long incised vertical lines with traces of added red (pseudo-tomgues); black-figure decoration consisting of upper part of bearded male dancer, to right (red on chest), with drinking horn (top remaining) in right hand and left arm outstretched; two ill-drawn dot rosettes as filling ornament.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
For a parallel regarding shoulder ornament, see Payne 1931, 304, no. 819.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 115-6, no. A193)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 220, no. 62)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.129) (Phase 1)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 72, pl. VI, no. 22)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
